Bandwidth Allocation for Multiple Federated Learning Services in Wireless Edge Networks

Jie Xu, Heqiang Wang, Lixing Chen J. Xu, H. Wang and L. Chen are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA.
Abstract

This paper studies a federated learning (FL) system, where multiple FL services co-exist in a wireless network and share common wireless resources. It fills the void of wireless resource allocation for multiple simultaneous FL services in the existing literature. Our method designs a two-level resource allocation framework comprising intra-service resource allocation and inter-service resource allocation. The intra-service resource allocation problem aims to minimize the length of FL rounds by optimizing the bandwidth allocation among the clients of each FL service. Based on this, an inter-service resource allocation problem is further considered, which distributes bandwidth resources among multiple simultaneous FL services. We consider both cooperative and selfish providers of the FL services. For cooperative FL service providers, we design a distributed bandwidth allocation algorithm to optimize the overall performance of multiple FL services, meanwhile cater to the fairness among FL services and the privacy of clients. For selfish FL service providers, a new auction scheme is designed with the FL service owners as the bidders and the network provider as the auctioneer. The designed auction scheme strikes a balance between the overall FL performance and fairness. Our simulation results show that the proposed algorithms outperform other benchmarks under various network conditions.

I Introduction

Today’s mobile devices are generating an unprecedented amount of data every day. Leveraging the recent success of machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI), this rich data has the potential to power a wide range of new functionalities and services, such as learning the activities of smart phone users, predicting health events from wearable devices or adapting to pedestrian behavior in autonomous vehicles. With the help of multi-access edge computing (MEC) servers, ML models can be quickly trained/updated using this data to adapt to the changing environment without moving the data to the remote cloud data center, which is envisioned in intelligent next-generation communication systems [1]. Furthermore, due to the growing storage and computational power of mobile devices as well as privacy concerns associated with uploading personal data, it is increasingly attractive to store and process data directly on mobile devices. Federate learning (FL) [2] is thus proposed as a new distributed ML framework, where mobile devices collaboratively train a shared ML model with the coordination of an edge server while keeping all the training data on device, thereby decoupling the ability to do ML from the need to upload/store the data to/in a public entity.

A typical FL service involves a number of mobile devices (a.k.a., participating clients) and an edge server (a.k.a., a parameter server) to train a ML model, which lasts for a number of learning rounds. In each round, the clients download the current ML model from the server, improve it by learning from their local data, and then upload the individual model updates to the server; the server then aggregates the local updates to improve the shared model. For example, the seminal work [3] proposed the FedAvg algorithm in which the global model is obtained by averaging the parameters of local models. Although other FL algorithms differ in the specifics, the majority of them follow the same procedure. Because the clients work in the same wireless network to download and upload models, how to allocate the limited wireless bandwidth among the participating clients has a crucial impact on the resulting FL speed and efficiency. Therefore, resource allocation for wireless FL systems is attracting much attention recently in the wireless communications community [4, 5]. Compared to resource allocation in traditional throughput-maximizing wireless networks, the resource allocation objective and outcome become considerably different for wireless FL due to its unique requirements and characteristics.

Although existing works have made meaningful progress towards efficient resource allocation for wireless FL, they share the common limitation that only a single FL service was considered. As ML-powered applications grow and become more diverse, it is anticipated that the wireless network will host multiple co-existing FL services, the set of which may also dynamically change over time. See Figure 1 for an illustration of the multi-FL service scenario. The presence of multiple FL services makes resource allocation for wireless FL much more challenging. First, the achievable FL performance depends on not only intra-service resource allocation among the participating clients within each FL service but also inter-service resource allocation among different FL services, and these two levels of allocation decisions are also strongly coupled. Second, the FL service providers may adopt different FL algorithms and choose different configurations (e.g., number of participating clients, number of epochs of local training, etc.), yet this information is not always available to the wireless network operator due to privacy concerns when making resource allocation decisions. Third, because FL service providers have their individual goals, they may have incentives to untruthfully reveal their valuation of the wireless bandwidth if by doing so they gain advantages in the inter-service bandwidth allocation. Without the correct information, there is no guarantee on the overall system performance. Finally, as in any multi-user system, resource allocation should strike a good balance between efficiency and fairness – every FL service provider should obtain a reasonable share of the wireless resource to train their ML models using FL.

In this paper, we make an initial effort to study wireless FL with multiple co-existing FL services, which share the same bandwidth to train their respective ML models. Our focus is on the efficient bandwidth allocation among different FL services as well as among the participating clients within each FL service, thereby understanding the interplay between these two levels of allocation decisions. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We formalize a two-level bandwidth allocation problem for multiple FL services co-existing in the wireless network, which may start and complete at different time depending on their own demand and FL requirements. The model is general enough for any FL algorithm that involves downloading, local learning, uploading and global aggregation in each learning round, and hence has wide applicability in real-world systems. In addition, we explicitly take fairness into consideration when optimizing bandwidth allocation to ensure that no FL service is starved of bandwidth.

  • •

    We consider two use cases depending on the nature/goals of the FL service providers. In the first case, FL service providers are fully cooperative to maximize the overall system performance. For this, we design a distributed optimization algorithm based on dual decomposition to solve the two-level bandwidth allocation problem. The algorithm keeps all FL-related information at the individual FL service provider side without sharing it with the network operator, thereby reducing the communication overhead and enhancing privacy protection.

  • •

    We further consider a second case where FL service providers are selfishly maximizing their own performance. To address the selfishness issue, we design a multi-bid auction mechanism, which is able to elicit the FL service providers’ truthful valuation of bandwidth based on their submitted bids. With a fairness-adjusted ex post charge, the proposed auction mechanism is able to make a tunable trade-off between efficiency and fairness.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II discusses related works. Section III builds the system model. Section IV formulates the problem for the cooperative case and develops a distributed bandwidth allocation algorithm. Section V studies the selfish service providers case and develops a multi-auction mechanism. Section VI performs simulations. Concluding remarks are made in Section VII.

II Related Work

A lot of research has been devoted to tackling various challenges of FL, including but not limited to developing new optimization and model aggregation methods [6, 7, 8], handling non-i.i.d. and unbalanced datasets [9, 10, 11], dealing with the straggler problem [12], preserving model and data privacy [13, 14], and ensuring fairness [15, 16]. A comprehensive review of these challenges can be found in [17, 18, 19]. In particular, the communication aspect of FL has been recognized as a primary bottleneck due to the tension between uploading a large amount of model data for aggregation and the limited network resource to support this transmission, especially in a wireless environment. In this regard, early research on communication-efficient FL largely focuses on reducing the amount of transmitted data while assuming that the underlying communication channel has been established, e.g., updating clients with significant training improvement [20], compressing the gradient vectors via quantization [21], or accelerating training using sparse or structured updates [22]. More recent research starts to address this problem from a more communication system perspective, e.g., using a hierarchical FL network architecture [23] that allows partial model aggregation, and leveraging the wireless transmission property to perform analog model aggregation over the air [24].

As wireless networks are envisioned as a main deployment scenario of FL, wireless resource allocation for FL is another active research topic. Many existing works [25, 26, 5] study the trade-off between local model update and global model aggregation. Client selection is essential to enable FL at scale and address the straggler problem. Different types of joint bandwidth allocation and client scheduling policies [27, 28, 29, 30, 31] have been proposed to either minimize the training loss or the training time. In all these works, resource allocation is carried out among clients of a single FL service, while assuming that the FL service itself has already received dedicated resource. In stark contrast, our paper studies a network consisting of multiple co-existing FL services and performs resource allocation at both the FL service level and the client level. We notice that a related problem where multiple FL services are being trained at the same time is also considered in a recent work [32]. In that paper, different FL services run on the same set of clients and a joint computation and communication resource scheduling problem is studied. In our paper, different FL services have their separate client sets which may experience very different channel qualities and hence we focus only on the bandwidth allocation problem. Moreover, while [32] assumed that all clients are obedient, we study the possible selfish nature of FL service providers and highlight bandwidth allocation fairness.

Considering each FL service as a “user”, our problem is a special type of resource allocation problems for multi-user wireless networks. While many concepts and techniques adopted in this paper, including proportional fairness [33], dual decomposition [34] and multi-bid auction [35], have seen applications in other multi-user wireless resource allocation domains, applying them in multi-service FL requires special treatment as two levels of resource allocation are involved in our problem. In particular, there is no closed-form expression of how the performance (i.e., learning speed) of a FL service depends on the resource allocation among its clients. Therefore, understanding the inter-dependency of intra-service and inter-service bandwidth allocation is essential. Furthermore, we put an emphasis on the resource fairness among different FL services by designing a new fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction mechanism in the selfish FL service provider case, thereby achieving a tunable tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. We point out that there are some existing works [36, 37, 38, 39] on designing incentive mechanisms for client participation of a single FL service. These works are very different from our paper in terms of both the problem and the approaches, and do not consider fairness when designing the mechanism.

III System Model

We consider a wireless network where machine learning models are trained using Federated Learning (FL). The wireless network has a total bandwidth B𝐵B, and the network operator has to allocate this bandwidth among concurrent FL services when needed to enable their individual training. Because new FL services may start and old FL services may finish over time, bandwidth allocation has to be periodically performed to adapt to the current active FL services. Therefore, we divide time into periods and let the length of a period be T𝑇T. At the beginning of each period i𝑖i, a set 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} of FL services are active and require wireless bandwidth to carry out their training. These services are either newly initiated services in period i𝑖i or continuing services from the previous period. A FL service finishes and hence exits the wireless network when a certain termination criteria is satisfied (e.g., the training loss is below a threshold, the testing accuracy is above a threshold, or other convergence criterion), which usually varies across FL services and are pre-specified by the corresponding service provider. Therefore, a FL service may span multiple periods. The wall clock time (i.e. the number of periods) that a FL service takes to finish depends on the difficulty and other inherent characteristics of the service itself as well as how much wireless resource is allocated to this service in each period for which it stays and how this bandwidth is further allocated among its participating clients. In what follows, we first formulate the client-level (i.e., intra-service) bandwidth allocation problem and then describe the service-level (i.e., inter-service) bandwidth allocation problem.

III-A Intra-Service Bandwidth Allocation

To understand how bandwidth allocation affects FL performance, let us consider a single representative FL service n𝑛n in one period (period index i𝑖i is dropped for conciseness). Suppose that this service is allocated with a bandwidth bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} in this period, which is further allocated among its participating clients, the set of which is denoted by 𝒦nsubscript𝒦𝑛\mathcal{K}_{n}. For each client k∈𝒦n𝑘subscript𝒦𝑛k\in\mathcal{K}_{n}, let ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} be its computing speed, and gkulsubscriptsuperscript𝑔ul𝑘g^{\text{ul}}_{k} and gkdlsubscriptsuperscript𝑔dl𝑘g^{\text{dl}}_{k} be the uplink and downlink wireless channel gains to the parameter server of service n𝑛n, respectively, which are assumed to be invariant within a period. We consider a synchronized FL model for each FL service, where a number of FL rounds take place in a period. Nonetheless, different FL services do not have to be synchronized – they learn at their own pace. See Figure 2 for an illustration.

A FL round consists of four stages: download transmission, local computation, upload transmission and global computation:

  • •

    Download Transmission (DT). Each FL round starts with a DT stage in which each client k𝑘k downloads the current global model from its parameter server residing on the base station. Suppose client k𝑘k is allocated with bandwidth bn,ksubscript𝑏𝑛𝑘b_{n,k}, then its DT rate is bn,k​log2⁡(1+Pn​gkdl/N0)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑘subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑔dl𝑘subscript𝑁0b_{n,k}\log_{2}(1+P_{n}g^{\text{dl}}_{k}/N_{0}) following Shannon’s equation, where Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} is the transmission power of parameter server n𝑛n and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power. For notational convenience, we denote log2⁡(1+Pn​gkdl/N0)≜rkDT≜subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑔dl𝑘subscript𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝑟DT𝑘\log_{2}(1+P_{n}g^{\text{dl}}_{k}/N_{0})\triangleq r^{\text{DT}}_{k} as the DT base rate of client k𝑘k.   • •

    Local Computation (LC). With the current global model, each client k𝑘k then updates its local model using its local dataset. Depending on the ML model complexity, the local dataset size and the number of episodes in local training, the per-round local computation workload is denoted by wn,kLCsubscriptsuperscript𝑤LC𝑛𝑘w^{\text{LC}}_{n,k}. Therefore, the LC latency of client k𝑘k is tn,kLC=wn,kLC/ϕksubscriptsuperscript𝑡LC𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑤LC𝑛𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘t^{\text{LC}}_{n,k}=w^{\text{LC}}_{n,k}/\phi_{k}.

  • •

    Upload Transmission (UT). Once local update is finished, client k𝑘k transmits the result to the parameter server n𝑛n. Given the bandwidth bn,ksubscript𝑏𝑛𝑘b_{n,k}, its UT rate is bn,k​log2⁡(1+Pk​gku​l/N0)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑘subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑢𝑙𝑘subscript𝑁0b_{n,k}\log_{2}(1+P_{k}g^{ul}_{k}/N_{0}), where Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} is the transmission power of client k𝑘k and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the noise power. Again, for notational convenience, we denote log2⁡(1+Pk​gku​l/N0)≜rkUT≜subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑢𝑙𝑘subscript𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝑟UT𝑘\log_{2}(1+P_{k}g^{ul}_{k}/N_{0})\triangleq r^{\text{UT}}_{k} as the UT base rate of client k𝑘k. Let snUTsubscriptsuperscript𝑠UT𝑛s^{\text{UT}}_{n} be the data size that has to be transmitted to the parameter server, then the UT latency of client k𝑘k is tn,kUT=snUT/(bn,k​rkUT)subscriptsuperscript𝑡UT𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑠UT𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑟UT𝑘t^{\text{UT}}_{n,k}=s^{\text{UT}}_{n}/(b_{n,k}r^{\text{UT}}_{k}).

  • •

    Global Computation (GC). Finally, once the local updates of all clients are received by parameter server n𝑛n, the global model is updated. Let wnGCsubscriptsuperscript𝑤GC𝑛w^{\text{GC}}_{n} be the global model update workload and ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} be the computing speed of parameter server n𝑛n, then the GC latency is tnGC=wnGC/ϕnsubscriptsuperscript𝑡GC𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑤GC𝑛subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛t^{\text{GC}}_{n}=w^{\text{GC}}_{n}/\phi_{n}.

Note that our framework is applicable to a vast set of FL algorithms (e.g., FedAvg, FedSGD) that can be chosen for service n𝑛n. For instance, the downloaded/uploaded data may be the model itself, the compressed version of the model, or the model gradient information. For the purpose of bandwidth allocation, it is sufficient to describe the FL service as a tuple ⟨snDT,{wn,kLC}k∈𝒦n,snUT,wnGC⟩subscriptsuperscript𝑠DT𝑛subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤LC𝑛𝑘𝑘subscript𝒦𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠UT𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑤GC𝑛\langle s^{\text{DT}}_{n},\{w^{\text{LC}}_{n,k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{n}},s^{\text{UT}}_{n},w^{\text{GC}}_{n}\rangle.

In synchronized FL, the parameter server updates the global model until it has received the local updates from all participating clients. Hence, the length of a FL round of service n𝑛n is determined by the total latency of the slowest client, i.e. tn=maxk∈𝒦n⁡(tn,kDT+tn,kLC+tn,kUT+tnGC)subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑡DT𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡LC𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡UT𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡GC𝑛t_{n}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{n}}(t^{\text{DT}}_{n,k}+t^{\text{LC}}_{n,k}+t^{\text{UT}}_{n,k}+t^{\text{GC}}_{n}). To minimize the FL round length tnsubscript𝑡𝑛t_{n} of service n𝑛n so that more FL rounds can be executed in a period, one has to optimally allocate bandwidth bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} among the clients of service n𝑛n. Given bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}, the intra-service bandwidth allocation problem can be formulated as

Then the optimal FL frequency of service n𝑛n is fn∗​(bn)=1/tn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})=1/t^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), which is used to represent the FL speed of service n𝑛n. Note that this means T⋅fn∗​(bn)⋅𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛T\cdot f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) FL rounds can be performed in one period.

III-B Inter-Service Bandwidth Allocation

In a period, multiple active FL services may be active and require wireless bandwidth to carry out learning. Since they share a total bandwidth B𝐵B, how this bandwidth is allocated among different services will determine their achievable learning frequencies fn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), thus the convergence speed in terms of the wall clock time. In this paper, we consider two scenarios depending on the goals of the FL service providers and how inter-service bandwidth allocation is implemented. In the first scenario, all FL service providers are cooperative, and their goal is to maximize the FL performance of the overall system. Therefore, it is equivalent to the network operator solving a system-wide optimization problem. In the second scenario, the FL service providers are selfish who care about only their own FL performance. As these service providers are competing for the limited bandwidth resource, addressing their incentive issues is crucial. In this paper, we design a fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction mechanism for the inter-service bandwidth allocation in this case. In the following two sections, we discuss these two scenarios separately.

IV Cooperative service providers

In the cooperative service providers scenario, the network operator directly decides the bandwidth allocation to maximize the overall system performance. As in any multi-user network, bandwidth allocation for multi-service FL has to address both efficiency and fairness – every active FL service should get a reasonable share of the bandwidth. Thus, we adopt the notion of proportional fairness [33], a metric widely used in multi-user resource allocation, and aim to solve the following optimization problem:

maxb1,…,bN​∑n=1Nlog⁡(1+fn∗​(bn))subscriptsubscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\displaystyle\max_{b_{1},...,b_{N}}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))
subject to ∑n=1Nbn=B​and​fn∗​(bn)​solves​(​1​),∀nsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵andsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛solvesitalic-(1italic-)for-all𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}=B~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})~{}\text{solves}~{}\eqref{clientBA},\forall n (2)

where we drop the period index i𝑖i and let N𝑁N be the number of active FL services in the period for conciseness. The objective function adds a “1” inside the logarithmic to ensure that the function value is always non-negative. This change has very little impact on the final allocation since the frequency is often much larger than 1 in a period. Note also that the above inter-service bandwidth allocation problem Eqn. (2) implicitly incorporates the intra-service problem as fn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) is the solution to Eqn. (1).

IV-A Optimal Solution to the Intra-Service Problem

Although we do not have a closed-form solution of tn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛t^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), a bi-section algorithm can be constructed to easily solve the above problem to obtain the optimal tn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛t^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) and consequently the optimal frequency fn∗​(bn)=1/tn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})=1/t^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) as a function of bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}. Lemma 1.

fn∗​(bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) is a differentiable, increasing and concave function for bn>0subscript𝑏𝑛0b_{n}>0.

Proof.

Let us consider the inverse function bn​(fn)subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛b_{n}(f_{n}) defined by Eqn. (7). It is easy to see that for fn∈[0,1/maxk⁡tn,kC)subscript𝑓𝑛01subscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘f_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}), bn​(Fn)subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝐹𝑛b_{n}(F_{n}) is a monotonically increasing function in fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} with bn​(0)=0subscript𝑏𝑛00b_{n}(0)=0 and bn​(fn)→∞→subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛b_{n}(f_{n})\to\infty as fn→1/maxk⁡tn,kc​p→subscript𝑓𝑛1subscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑐𝑝𝑛𝑘f_{n}\to 1/\max_{k}t^{cp}_{n,k}. Therefore, for bn≥0subscript𝑏𝑛0b_{n}\geq 0, fn​(bn)subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f_{n}(b_{n}) is also monotonically increasing. The first-order derivative of bn​(fn)subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛b_{n}(f_{n}) is

bn′=d​bnd​fn=d​bnd​tn​d​tnd​fn=∑kαn,k(1−tn,kC​fn)2>0,∀fn∈[0,1/maxk⁡tn,kC)formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑛𝑑subscript𝑏𝑛𝑑subscript𝑓𝑛𝑑subscript𝑏𝑛𝑑subscript𝑡𝑛𝑑subscript𝑡𝑛𝑑subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘superscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘subscript𝑓𝑛20for-allsubscript𝑓𝑛01subscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘\displaystyle b^{\prime}_{n}=\frac{db_{n}}{df_{n}}=\frac{db_{n}}{dt_{n}}\frac{dt_{n}}{df_{n}}=\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}>0,\forall f_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}) (8)

Therefore, fn​(bn)subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f_{n}(b_{n}) is differentiable for bn≥0subscript𝑏𝑛0b_{n}\geq 0 and

fn′=d​fnd​bn=(∑kαn,k(1−tn,kC​fn)2)−1>0,∀bn≥0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑛𝑑subscript𝑓𝑛𝑑subscript𝑏𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘superscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘subscript𝑓𝑛210for-allsubscript𝑏𝑛0\displaystyle f^{\prime}_{n}=\frac{df_{n}}{db_{n}}=\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}\right)^{-1}>0,\forall b_{n}\geq 0 (9)

The second-order derivative fn′′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′′𝑛f^{\prime\prime}_{n} can also be computed as follows:

fn′′=−(∑kαn,k(1−tn,kC​fn)2)−2​(∑kαn,k​tn,kC(1−tn,kC​fn)3)<0,∀B≥0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑓′′𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘superscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝐶𝑛𝑘subscript𝑓𝑛22subscript𝑘subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘superscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘subscript𝑓𝑛30for-all𝐵0\displaystyle f^{\prime\prime}_{n}=-\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{C}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}\right)^{-2}\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{3}}\right)<0,\forall B\geq 0 (10)

This proves that fn​(bn)subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛f_{n}(b_{n}) is a concave function for bn≥0subscript𝑏𝑛0b_{n}\geq 0. ∎

With Lemma 1, it is straightforward to see that the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is a convex optimization problem.

Proposition 1.

The inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is an equality-constrained convex optimization problem.

Proof.

Because f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is concave, log\log is concave and increasing, the composition log⁡(1+f∗)1superscript𝑓\log(1+f^{*}) is also a concave function. Then it is straightforward to see that the problem is a concave maximization problem with an equality constraint. ∎

IV-B Distributed Algorithm for Inter-Service Bandwidth Allocation

We now proceed with solving the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem. While various centralized algorithms, such the Newton’s method, can efficiently solve the inter-service problem Eqn. (2) given the fact that it is a convex optimization problem, we prefer a distributed algorithm where individual FL service providers do not share their FL algorithm details and client-level information with each other or the network operator. This way reduces the communication overhead and preserves privacy of the client devices of individual FL service providers. Our algorithm is developed based on dual decomposition [34] as follows.

We first relax the total bandwidth constraint ∑nbn=Bsubscript𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵\sum_{n}b_{n}=B to be ∑nbn≤Bsubscript𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵\sum_{n}b_{n}\leq B, and then form the Lagrangian by relaxing the coupling constraint:

L​(b1,…,bN,λ)=∑nlog⁡(1+fn∗​(bn))−λ​(∑nbn−B)=∑nLn​(bn,λ)+λ​B𝐿subscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑁𝜆subscript𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscript𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵subscript𝑛subscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝜆𝐵\displaystyle L(b_{1},...,b_{N},\lambda)=\sum_{n}\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda\left(\sum_{n}b_{n}-B\right)=\sum_{n}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)+\lambda B (11)

where λ𝜆\lambda is the Lagrange multipier associated with the total bandwidth constraint, and Ln​(bn,λ)=log⁡(1+fn∗​(bn))−λ​bnsubscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscript𝑏𝑛L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda b_{n} is the Lagrangian to be maximized by service provider n𝑛n. Such dual decomposition results in each service provider n𝑛n solving, for a given λ𝜆\lambda, the following problem

bn∗​(λ)=arg⁡maxbn≥0⁡Ln​(bn,λ)=arg⁡maxbn≥0⁡(log⁡(1+fn∗​(bn))−λ​bn)subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛0subscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛01subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscript𝑏𝑛\displaystyle b^{*}_{n}(\lambda)=\arg\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=\arg\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}\left(\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda b_{n}\right) (12)

where the solution is unique due to the strict concavity of fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n} according to Lemma 1. Specifically, to solve this maximization problem, we only need to solve its first-order condition,

fn∗′​(bn)/(1+fn∗​(bn))=λsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛′subscript𝑏𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆\displaystyle{f_{n}^{*}}^{\prime}(b_{n})/(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))=\lambda (13)

which can be converted to solve f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} using

(1+fn∗)​∑k∈𝒦nαn,k(1−tn,kC​fn∗)2=λ−11subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑛subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘superscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛2superscript𝜆1\displaystyle(1+f^{*}_{n})\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{n}}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f^{*}_{n})^{2}}=\lambda^{-1} (14)

Clearly, the left-hand side is an increasing function of fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n} for fn∗∈[0,1/maxk⁡tn,kC)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛01subscript𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑡C𝑛𝑘f^{*}_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}) and thus, a simple bi-section algorithm can be devised to solve Eqn. (14) to obtain fn∗​(λ)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝜆f^{*}_{n}(\lambda). Then plugging fn∗​(λ)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝜆f^{*}_{n}(\lambda) (hence tn∗​(λ)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑛𝜆t^{*}_{n}(\lambda)) into Eqn. (7) yields the optimal bn∗​(λ)subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆b^{*}_{n}(\lambda).

Let gn​(λ)=maxbn≥0⁡Ln​(bn,λ)=Ln​(bn∗​(λ),λ)subscript𝑔𝑛𝜆subscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛0subscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆subscript𝐿𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝜆g_{n}(\lambda)=\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=L_{n}(b^{*}_{n}(\lambda),\lambda) be the local dual function for service provider n𝑛n. Then the master dual problem is

minλ⁡g​(λ)=∑ngn​(λ)+λ​Bsubject to​λ≥0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑔𝜆subscript𝑛subscript𝑔𝑛𝜆𝜆𝐵subject to𝜆0\displaystyle\min_{\lambda}g(\lambda)=\sum_{n}g_{n}(\lambda)+\lambda B~{}~{}~{}~{}\text{subject to}~{}~{}\lambda\geq 0 (15)

Since bn∗​(λ)subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆b^{*}_{n}(\lambda) is unique, it follows that the dual function gn​(λ)subscript𝑔𝑛𝜆g_{n}(\lambda) is differentiable and the following gradient method can be used to iteratively update λ𝜆\lambda:

λ​(j+1)=[λ​(j)−γ​(B−∑nbn∗​(λ​(j)))]+𝜆𝑗1superscriptdelimited-[]𝜆𝑗𝛾𝐵subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝑗\displaystyle\lambda(j+1)=\left[\lambda(j)-\gamma\left(B-\sum_{n}b^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j))\right)\right]^{+} (16)

where j𝑗j is the iteration index, γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is a sufficiently small positive step-size, and [⋅]+superscriptdelimited-[]⋅[\cdot]^{+} denotes the projection onto the non-negative orthant. The dual variable λ​(j)𝜆𝑗\lambda(j) will converge to the dual optimum λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} as j→∞→𝑗j\to\infty. Since the duality gap for the inter-service problem Eqn. (2) is zero and the solution to Eqn. (12) is unique, the primal variable bn∗​(λ​(j))subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝑗b^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) will also converge to the primal optimal variable bn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛b^{*}_{n}.

Algorithm 1 summarizes the distributed inter-service bandwidth allocation (DISBA) algorithm. The algorithm works iteratively. In each iteration, the operator sends the current λ​(j)𝜆𝑗\lambda(j) to all service providers. Then, each service providers solves for bn∗​(λ​(j))subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝑗b^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) using its local information and sends the result to the network operator. The network operator finally updates λ​(j+1)𝜆𝑗1\lambda(j+1) for the next iteration’s computation. The algorithm terminates until λ𝜆\lambda converges.

V Selfish service providers

In the previous section, the distributed inter-service bandwidth allocation works by letting each FL service provider compute the allocated bandwidth bn∗​(λ​(j))subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑛𝜆𝑗b^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) given λ​(j)𝜆𝑗\lambda(j). This, however, creates an opportunity for a selfish service provider to mis-report its computation result that favors itself but reduces the system performance as a whole. In fact, even if the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is solved in a centralized way, similar selfish behavior may still undermine the efficient system operation as a selfish service provider may mis-report its FL service and client parameters (e.g., FL workload, client computing power and channel gains etc.), which will alter the frequency function fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n} used at the operator side. With a wrong frequency function fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n}, the operator will not be able to determine the true optimal bandwidth allocation.

In this section, we address the selfishness issue in inter-service bandwidth allocation by designing a multi-bid auction mechanism. This auction mechanism will ensure that the FL service providers are using their true FL frequency functions fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n} when making bandwidth bids.

V-A Multi-bid Auction

First, we describe the general rules of the multi-bid auction mechanism.

V-A1 Bidding

At the beginning of each bandwidth allocation period, each service provider n𝑛n submits a set of M𝑀M bids sn={sn1,…,snM}subscript𝑠𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠1𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑀𝑛s_{n}=\{s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}\}. For each m∈{1,…,M}𝑚1…𝑀m\in\{1,...,M\}, snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛s^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is a two-dimensional bid, where bnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛b^{m}_{n} is the requested bandwidth and pnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛p^{m}_{n} is the unit price that service provider n𝑛n is willing to pay to get the requested bandwidth bnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛b^{m}_{n}. Without loss of generality, we assume that bids are sorted according to the price such that pn1≤pn2≤…≤pnMsubscriptsuperscript𝑝1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝2𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑀𝑛p^{1}_{n}\leq p^{2}_{n}\leq...\leq p^{M}_{n}. Let S∈ℝ+×ℝ+𝑆superscriptℝsuperscriptℝS\in\mathbb{R}^{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{+} denote the set of multi-bids that a service provider can submit.

V-A2 Bandwidth Allocation and Charges

Once the network operator collects all multi-bids from all service providers, denoted by s={sn}n∈𝒩𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑛𝒩s=\{s_{n}\}_{n\in\mathcal{N}}, it computes and implements the inter-service bandwidth allocation (b1,…,bN)subscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑁(b_{1},...,b_{N}). Each service provider n𝑛n then further allocates bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} to its clients to perform FL. At the end of the period, the network operator determines the charges (c1,…,cN)subscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑁(c_{1},...,c_{N}) for all service providers depending on the allocated bandwidth and the realized FL performance.

Now, a couple of issues remain to be addressed. First, how to compute the bandwidth allocation and determine the charges given the service provider-submitted multi-bids? Second, do the service providers have incentives to truthfully report their valuations of the bandwidth? These are the questions to be addressed in the next subsections.

V-B Market Clearing Prices with Full Information

We first consider a simpler case where the service providers truthfully report the complete FL frequency function fn∗​(b),∀nsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏for-all𝑛f^{*}_{n}(b),\forall n to the network operator. This analysis will provide us with insights on how to design bandwidth allocation and charging rules in the more difficult multi-bid auction case.

Recall that fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b) is the optimal FL frequency of service n𝑛n if it has bandwidth b𝑏b. Taking into account the price paid to obtain this bandwidth, the (net) utility of service provider n𝑛n is

un​(b;p)=fn∗​(b)−p⋅bsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑏𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏⋅𝑝𝑏\displaystyle u_{n}(b;p)=f^{*}_{n}(b)-p\cdot b (17)

Now, if the bandwidth were sold at the unit price p𝑝p, then service provider n𝑛n would buy bn​(p)=arg⁡maxb⁡un​(b;p)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑝subscript𝑏subscript𝑢𝑛𝑏𝑝b_{n}(p)=\arg\max_{b}u_{n}(b;p) bandwidth in order to maximize its utility. We call bn​(p)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑝b_{n}(p) the bandwidth demand function (BDF), and it is easy to show that bn​(p)=(fn∗′)−1​(p)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑝superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′1𝑝b_{n}(p)=({f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime})^{-1}(p) by checking the first-order condition of Eqn. (17). On the other hand, if service provider n𝑛n requires a bandwidth b𝑏b, then the service provider would pay a unit price no more than pn​(b)=fn∗′​(b)subscript𝑝𝑛𝑏superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′𝑏p_{n}(b)={f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b). We call pn​(b)subscript𝑝𝑛𝑏p_{n}(b) the marginal valuation function (MVF).

V-B1 Market clearing price

With the complete information of fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b) and hence BDF bn​(p)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑝b_{n}(p) for all service providers, the network operator can compute the market clearing price (MCP) ρ𝜌\rho so that ∑n=1Nbn​(ρ)=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝜌𝐵\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(\rho)=B. One can prove that the MCP is unique and optimal in the sense that it maximizes the total (equivalently, average) FL frequency.

Proposition 2.

The market clearing price ρ𝜌\rho is unique and maximizes the total FL frequency ∑n=1Nfn∗​(bn)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}).

Proof.

According to Lemma 1, fn∗′​(b)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′𝑏{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b) is an increasing function. Therefore, the BDF, which is the inverse function of fn∗′​(b)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′𝑏{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b) is also increasing. As a result, there exists a unique solution to the increasing function ∑n=1Nbn​(pn)=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝐵\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(p_{n})=B.

To show that p¯¯𝑝\bar{p} maximizes ∑n=1Nfn∗​(bn)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), consider the following maximization problem

maxb1,…,bN​∑n=1Nfn∗​(bn)​subject to​∑n=1Nbn=Bsubscriptsubscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛subject tosuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵\displaystyle\max_{b_{1},...,b_{N}}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})~{}~{}~{}\text{subject to}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}=B (18)

This is clearly a convex optimization problem. Consider its Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions. In particular, the stationarity condition is

∇​∑n=1Nfn∗​(bn)+λ​∇(∑n=1Nbn−B)=0∇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆∇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝐵0\displaystyle\nabla\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})+\lambda\nabla(\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}-B)=0 (19)

where λ𝜆\lambda is the Lagrangian multiplier associated with the constraint. The solution requires

fn∗′​(bn)=λ,∀nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′subscript𝑏𝑛𝜆for-all𝑛\displaystyle{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b_{n})=\lambda,\forall n (20)

Together with the feasibility constraint, this is equivalent to imposing a homogeneous market clearing price. ∎

Because bn​(p)subscript𝑏𝑛𝑝b_{n}(p) is a monotonically decreasing function in p𝑝p, a bi-section algorithm can be easily designed to find the unique market clearing price so that ∑n=1Nbn​(ρ)=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑏𝑛𝜌𝐵\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(\rho)=B.

V-B2 Fairness-adjusted costs

One major issue with the above pricing scheme is that it ignores fairness among the service providers: although it maximizes efficiency in terms of the average FL frequency according to Proposition 2, it is possible that the average FL frequency is maximized at an operating point where a few service providers are allocated with most of the bandwidth while some service providers obtain very little bandwidth. In this paper, we design and incorporate a fairness-adjusted charging scheme into the above pricing scheme. The payment of service provider n𝑛n now consists of two parts as follows:

  • •

    The first part of the payment depends on the amount of bandwidth bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} allocated to the service provider n𝑛n, and the unit price p𝑝p set by the operator. Specifically, this payment is p⋅bn⋅𝑝subscript𝑏𝑛p\cdot b_{n}.

  • •

    The second part of the payment depends on the realized FL frequency fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} of service provider n𝑛n. Specifically, service provider n𝑛n will be charged a fairness-adjusted cost of α⋅(fn−log⁡(1+fn))⋅𝛼subscript𝑓𝑛1subscript𝑓𝑛\alpha\cdot(f_{n}-\log(1+f_{n})) at the end of the period once fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} has been realized, where α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] is a tunable parameter.

With these payments, service provider n𝑛n’s utility becomes

un​(b;p)=fn∗​(b)−p⋅b−α⋅(fn∗​(b)−log⁡(1+fn∗​(b)))=gn​(b)−p⋅bsubscript𝑢𝑛𝑏𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏⋅𝑝𝑏⋅𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏⋅𝑝𝑏\displaystyle u_{n}(b;p)=f^{*}_{n}(b)-p\cdot b-\alpha\cdot(f^{*}_{n}(b)-\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)))=g_{n}(b)-p\cdot b (21)

where gn​(b)≜(1−α)​fn∗​(b)+α​log⁡(1+fn∗​(b))≜subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏1𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b)\triangleq(1-\alpha)f^{*}_{n}(b)+\alpha\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)). Comparing this new utility function Eqn. (21) with Eqn. (17), we make the following remarks. First, the fairness-adjusted cost essentially replaces fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b) with gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b). The decision problem remains largely the same except that now we have a different benefit function. Second, in the new utility function Eqn. (17), given any allocated bandwidth b𝑏b, it is still in the service provider’s interest to perform the optimal client-level bandwidth allocation to maximize fn​(b)subscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f_{n}(b). This is because gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) is an increasing function in fn​(b)subscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f_{n}(b) for α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]. Therefore, we can directly write gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) as a function of the optimal FL frequency fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b). Third, to charge the fairness-adjusted cost, the network operator does not need to know the exact function fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b). Rather, it only has to know the realized FL frequency fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} at the end of the current period. This is key to achieving fairness in multi-bid auction where FL service providers do not report the complete FL frequency function fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b).

We call dn​(p)=(gn′)−1​(p)subscript𝑑𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛1𝑝d_{n}(p)=(g^{\prime}_{n})^{-1}(p) the modified bandwidth demand function (mBDF). Likewise, we call qn​(b)=gn′​(b)subscript𝑞𝑛𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛𝑏q_{n}(b)=g^{\prime}_{n}(b) the modified marginal valuation function (mMVF). The network operator can similarly compute the modified market clearing price (mMCP) ζ𝜁\zeta so that ∑n=1Ndn​(ζ)=Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑑𝑛𝜁𝐵\sum_{n=1}^{N}d_{n}(\zeta)=B. Using a similar argument that proves Proposition 2, one can prove Proposition 3 as follows.

Proposition 3.

The mMCP ζ𝜁\zeta is unique and the resulting bandwidth allocation (b1,…,bN)subscript𝑏1…subscript𝑏𝑁(b_{1},...,b_{N}) maximizes ∑n=1N[(1−α)​fn∗​(bn)+α​log⁡(1+fn∗​(b))]superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁delimited-[]1𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[(1-\alpha)f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})+\alpha\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b))\right].

Proof.

Because fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b) is a concave increasing function, log⁡(1+fn∗​(b))1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)) is also concave and increasing. This further shows that gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) is concave and increasing. Following similar arguments in the proof of Theorem 2 proves the bandwidth allocation as a result of mMCP maximizes ∑n=1Ngn​(bn)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑔𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}g_{n}(b_{n}). ∎

The parameter α𝛼\alpha makes a tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. On the one hand, setting α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 reduces the problem to the total FL frequency maximization problem. On the other hand, setting α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 achieves proportional fairness among the service providers.

V-C Bandwidth Allocation and Charging Rules

Now, we are ready to describe the bandwidth allocation and charging rules in fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction. In this subsection, each service provider n𝑛n submits only a multi-bid sn=(sn1,…,snM)subscript𝑠𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠1𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑀𝑛s_{n}=(s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}) instead of the complete FL frequency function fn∗​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑏f^{*}_{n}(b). However, we will assume that the service providers are truthfully submitting their bids, which will be proven indeed true in the next subsection. Specifically, we say that a bid snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛s^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is truthful if the bandwidth demand bnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛b^{m}_{n} and the price pnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛p^{m}_{n} that FL service provider n𝑛n is willing to pay satisfy the mBDF because it reveals FL service provider n𝑛n’s true valuation of bandwidth after taking into consideration the fairness-adjusted costs. A multi-bid is truthful if all bids are truthful.

Definition 1.

(Truthful Multi-bid) A multi-bid sn=(sn1,…,snM)subscript𝑠𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠1𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑀𝑛s_{n}=(s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}) is truthful if ∀mfor-all𝑚\forall m, snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛s^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is such that pnm=gn′​(bnm)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛′subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛p^{m}_{n}=g_{n}^{\prime}(b^{m}_{n}).

The network operator does not know the BDF (and hence the mBDF) of each FL service provider n𝑛n because it does not have access to the FL frequency function fn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛f^{*}_{n}. Nonetheless, suppose service provider n𝑛n submitted a truthful multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n}, then the operator can compute a pseudo-mBDF using these bids to have some idea of the actual mBDF. Specifically, given the submitted multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n}, a left-continuous step function can be used to describe the pseudo-mBDF as follows,

d¯n​(p)={0,if​pnM<pmax1≤m≤M⁡{bnm:pnm≥p},otherwisesubscript¯𝑑𝑛𝑝cases0ifsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑀𝑛𝑝subscript1𝑚𝑀:subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛𝑝otherwise\bar{d}_{n}(p)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{if}~{}p^{M}_{n}<p\\ \max_{1\leq m\leq M}\{b^{m}_{n}:p^{m}_{n}\geq p\},&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (22)

Essentially, the pseudo-mBDF uses bnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛b^{m}_{n} to approximate the bandwidth demand for prices in the range (pnm−1,pnm]subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛(p^{m-1}_{n},p^{m}_{n}]. Similarly, the operator can also construct a pseudo-mMVF (pseudo-MVF), an approximation of service provider n𝑛n’s actual mMVF using the submitted multi-bid, as follows,

q¯n​(b)={0,if​bn1<bmax1≤m≤M⁡{pnm:bnm≥b},otherwisesubscript¯𝑞𝑛𝑏cases0ifsubscriptsuperscript𝑏1𝑛𝑏subscript1𝑚𝑀:subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛𝑏otherwise\bar{q}_{n}(b)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{if}~{}b^{1}_{n}<b\\ \max_{1\leq m\leq M}\{p^{m}_{n}:b^{m}_{n}\geq b\},&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (23)

In other words, the pseudo-mMVF uses pnmsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛p^{m}_{n} to approximate the marginal value for bandwidth allocation in the range [bnm,bnm+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑚1𝑛[b^{m}_{n},b^{m+1}_{n}). We illustrate the pseudo-mBDF and pseudo-mMVF in Figure 3.

The aggregated pseudo-mBDF is the sum of pseudo-mBDFs of all FL service providers:

d¯​(p)=∑n=1Nd¯n​(p)¯𝑑𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript¯𝑑𝑛𝑝\displaystyle\bar{d}(p)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\bar{d}_{n}(p) (24)

The pseudo-mMCP ζ¯¯𝜁\bar{\zeta} is the largest possible price so that the aggregated pseudo-mBDF exceeds the total available bandwidth, i.e.,

ζ¯=sup{p:d¯​(p)>B}¯𝜁supremumconditional-set𝑝¯𝑑𝑝𝐵\displaystyle\bar{\zeta}=\sup\{p:\bar{d}(p)>B\} (25)

This implies that reducing the mMCP by just a little bit will result in the supply (i.e., the total available bandwidth B𝐵B) being no greater than the demand. Because every individual pseudo-mBDF function is a step function with K𝐾K steps, the aggregated pseudo-mBDF is also a step function with at most N​K𝑁𝐾NK steps. Therefore, the complexity of computing ζ¯¯𝜁\bar{\zeta} is at most O​(N​K)𝑂𝑁𝐾O(NK).

Next, we describe our bandwidth allocation and charging rules. For notational convenience, we denote y​(x+)=limz→x,z>xy​(x)𝑦superscript𝑥subscriptformulae-sequence→𝑧𝑥𝑧𝑥𝑦𝑥y(x^{+})=\lim_{z\to x,z>x}y(x) when this limit exists for a function y:ℝ→ℝ:𝑦→ℝℝy:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} and all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}.

V-C1 Bandwidth allocation

With the pseudo-mMCP ζ¯¯𝜁\bar{\zeta}, our bandwidth allocation rule is as follows: if FL service provider n𝑛n submits the multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} (and thereby declares the associated functions d¯nsubscript¯𝑑𝑛\bar{d}_{n} and q¯nsubscript¯𝑞𝑛\bar{q}_{n}), then it receives bandwidth bn​(sn,s−n)subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n}), with

bn​(sn,s−n)=d¯n​(ζ¯+)+d¯n​(ζ¯)−d¯n​(ζ¯+)d¯​(ζ¯)−d¯​(ζ¯+)​(B−d¯​(ζ¯+))subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript¯𝑑𝑛superscript¯𝜁subscript¯𝑑𝑛¯𝜁subscript¯𝑑𝑛superscript¯𝜁¯𝑑¯𝜁¯𝑑superscript¯𝜁𝐵¯𝑑superscript¯𝜁\displaystyle b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})=\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})+\frac{\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})}{\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})}\left(B-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})\right) (26)

In other words: (1) Each FL service provider n𝑛n receives an amount of bandwidth it asks for at the lowest price ζ¯+superscript¯𝜁\bar{\zeta}^{+} for which supply exceeds the pseudo-bandwidth demand. (2) If all bandwidth is not allocated yet, the surplus B−d¯​(ζ¯+)𝐵¯𝑑superscript¯𝜁B-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+}) is shared among service providers. This share is done proportionally to d¯n​(ζ¯)−d¯n​(ζ¯+)subscript¯𝑑𝑛¯𝜁subscript¯𝑑𝑛superscript¯𝜁\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+}) as we notice that d¯​(ζ¯)−d¯​(ζ¯+)=∑n=1N(d¯n​(ζ¯)−d¯n​(ζ¯+))¯𝑑¯𝜁¯𝑑superscript¯𝜁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript¯𝑑𝑛¯𝜁subscript¯𝑑𝑛superscript¯𝜁\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})\right), and ensures that all bandwidth is allocated.

V-C2 Charging

Given the submitted multi-bids s𝑠s, each service provider n𝑛n is charged a payment cn​(s)subscript𝑐𝑛𝑠c_{n}(s) as follows,

cn​(sn,s−n)=∑j≠n∫bj​(s)bj​(s−n)q¯j​(b)​𝑑b+α⋅(fn∗​(bn)−log⁡(1+fn∗​(bn)))subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑗𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑠subscript𝑏𝑗subscript𝑠𝑛subscript¯𝑞𝑗𝑏differential-d𝑏⋅𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\displaystyle c_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})=\sum_{j\neq n}\int_{b_{j}(s)}^{b_{j}(s_{-n})}\bar{q}_{j}(b)db+\alpha\cdot(f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})-\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))) (27)

The first term on the right-hand side is based on the exclusion-compensation principle in second-price auction mechanisms [40]: service provider n𝑛n pays so as to cover the “social opportunity cost”, namely the loss of utility it imposes on all other service providers by its presence. The second term on the right-hand side is the fairness-adjusted cost, which is charged at the end of each period after the actual FL frequency is realized and observed.

Considering both the achieved FL frequency and the payment, FL service provider n𝑛n’s utility is therefore

u​(s)=fn∗​(bn​(s))−cn​(s)𝑢𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛𝑠subscript𝑐𝑛𝑠\displaystyle u(s)=f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}(s))-c_{n}(s) (28)

V-D Incentives of Truthful Reporting

In the previous subsection, we assumed that the every service provider truthfully submits its bid. Now, we prove that this assumption indeed “approximately” holds under the designed bandwidth allocation and charging rules.

We first study the individual rationality of the designed mechanism.

Definition 2.

A mechanism is said to be individual rational if no service provider can be worse off from participating in the auction than if it had declined to participate.

Proposition 4.

If FL service provider n𝑛n submits a truthful multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n}, then un​(s)≥0subscript𝑢𝑛𝑠0u_{n}(s)\geq 0.

Proof.

By Lemma 1, it is straightforward to see that gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) has the following properties:

  • •

    gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) is differentiable and gn​(0)=0subscript𝑔𝑛00g_{n}(0)=0

  • •

    gn′​(b)subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛𝑏g^{\prime}_{n}(b) is positive, non-increasing and continuous

  • •

    ∃γn>0subscript𝛾𝑛0\exists\gamma_{n}>0, ∀b≥0for-all𝑏0\forall b\geq 0, gn′​(b)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛𝑏0g^{\prime}_{n}(b)=0 ⇒⇒\Rightarrow ∀b~<bfor-all~𝑏𝑏\forall\tilde{b}<b, gn′​(b)≤gn′​(b~)−γn​(b−b~)subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑔′𝑛~𝑏subscript𝛾𝑛𝑏~𝑏g^{\prime}_{n}(b)\leq g^{\prime}_{n}(\tilde{b})-\gamma_{n}(b-\tilde{b}).

Therefore, gn​(b)subscript𝑔𝑛𝑏g_{n}(b) satisfies [Assumption 1, [35]]. According to [Property 10, [35]], we have

∑j≠n∫bj​(s)bj​(s−n)q¯j​(b)​𝑑b≤gn​(bn​(sn,s−n))subscript𝑗𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑠subscript𝑏𝑗subscript𝑠𝑛subscript¯𝑞𝑗𝑏differential-d𝑏subscript𝑔𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{j\neq n}\int_{b_{j}(s)}^{b_{j}(s_{-n})}\bar{q}_{j}(b)db\leq g_{n}(b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})) (29)

which is equivalent to cn​(sn,s−n)≤fn∗​(bn​(sn,s−n))subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛c_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})\leq f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})). Therefore, u​(s)≥0𝑢𝑠0u(s)\geq 0. ∎

Next, we show that truthful reporting is approximately incentive compatible, i.e., a service provider cannot do much better than simply reveal its true valuation.

Proposition 5.

Consider any truthful multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} for service provider n𝑛n, and any other multi-bid s~n≠snsubscript~𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛\tilde{s}_{n}\neq s_{n}, ∀s−nfor-allsubscript𝑠𝑛\forall s_{-n}, we have

un​(sn,s−n)≥un​(s~n,s−n)−Δnsubscript𝑢𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscript𝑢𝑛subscript~𝑠𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛subscriptΔ𝑛\displaystyle u_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})\geq u_{n}(\tilde{s}_{n},s_{-n})-\Delta_{n} (30)

where

Δn=max0≤m≤M​∫dn​(pnm+1)dn​(pnm)(qn​(b)−pnm)​𝑑bsubscriptΔ𝑛subscript0𝑚𝑀superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛differential-d𝑏\displaystyle\Delta_{n}=\max_{0\leq m\leq M}\int_{d_{n}(p^{m+1}_{n})}^{d_{n}(p^{m}_{n})}(q_{n}(b)-p^{m}_{n})db (31)

with pnM+1=qn​(0)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑀1𝑛subscript𝑞𝑛0p^{M+1}_{n}=q_{n}(0) and pn0=p0subscriptsuperscript𝑝0𝑛subscript𝑝0p^{0}_{n}=p_{0}.

Proof.

The proof follows [Proposition 2, [35]]. ∎

The above proposition shows that if service provider n𝑛n submits a truthful multi-bid snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n}, then every other multi-bid s~nsubscript~𝑠𝑛\tilde{s}_{n} necessarily corresponds to an increase of utility no larger than ΔnsubscriptΔ𝑛\Delta_{n}. In other words, a truthful bidding brings service provider n𝑛n the best utility possible up to a gap ΔnsubscriptΔ𝑛\Delta_{n}. Importantly, this value does not depend on the number of other service providers or the multi-bids they submit. In the game theoretic terminology, the situation where all service providers submit truthful multi-bids is an ex post ΔΔ\Delta-Nash equilibrium, where Δ=maxn⁡ΔnΔsubscript𝑛subscriptΔ𝑛\Delta=\max_{n}\Delta_{n}, in the sense that no service provider could have improved its utility by more than ΔΔ\Delta if it had submitted a different multi-bid.

V-E An Uniform Multi-Bidding Example

To conclude the multi-bid auction mechanism design, we illustrate a uniform multi-bidding approach as an example of how to decide the multi-bid of an individual service provider. Instead of having the service provider submitting both prices and bandwidth requests, the operator can announce M𝑀M prices (pn1,…,pnM)subscriptsuperscript𝑝1𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑀𝑛(p^{1}_{n},...,p^{M}_{n}) to service provider n𝑛n and let service provider n𝑛n report its requested bandwidth (bn1,…,bMM)subscriptsuperscript𝑏1𝑛…subscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑀𝑀(b^{1}_{n},...,b^{M}_{M}) at these price points. This way, the operator has a better control over how the service providers make multi-bids to avoid multi-bids that may result in a large ΔnsubscriptΔ𝑛\Delta_{n}, which may reduce service provider’s incentives to truthfully report. Because the operator does not know the demand function of service provider n𝑛n, a natural approach is to uniformly distribute these M𝑀M prices in the range [p0,pnmax]subscript𝑝0subscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛[p_{0},p^{\text{max}}_{n}] where pnmaxsubscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛p^{\text{max}}_{n} is the largest price at which the service provider may still request a positive amount of bandwidth. Specifically,

pnmax=pn​(0)=fn∗′​(0)=(∑k=1Knαn,k)−1=(∑k=1Kn(snDTrkDT+snUTrkUT))−1subscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛0superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛′0superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑛subscript𝛼𝑛𝑘1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑠DT𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑟DT𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑠UT𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑟UT𝑘1\displaystyle p^{\text{max}}_{n}=p_{n}(0)={f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(0)=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K_{n}}\alpha_{n,k}\right)^{-1}=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K_{n}}(\frac{s^{\text{DT}}_{n}}{r^{\text{DT}}_{k}}+\frac{s^{\text{UT}}_{n}}{r^{\text{UT}}_{k}})\right)^{-1} (32)

Assume that the network operator has prior knowledge K¯nsubscript¯𝐾𝑛\underline{K}_{n}, s¯nDTsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑠DT𝑛\underline{s}^{\text{DT}}_{n}, s¯nUTsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑠UT𝑛\underline{s}^{\text{UT}}_{n}, r¯nDTsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑟DT𝑛\bar{r}^{\text{DT}}_{n} and r¯nUTsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑟UT𝑛\bar{r}^{\text{UT}}_{n} on the lower/upper bounds on the parameters, then pnmaxsubscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛p^{\text{max}}_{n} can be upper bounded by

pnmax≤K¯n−1⋅(s¯nDTr¯nDT+s¯nUTr¯nUT)−1≜p¯nmaxsubscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛⋅superscriptsubscript¯𝐾𝑛1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑠DT𝑛subscriptsuperscript¯𝑟DT𝑛subscriptsuperscript¯𝑠UT𝑛subscriptsuperscript¯𝑟UT𝑛1≜subscriptsuperscript¯𝑝max𝑛\displaystyle p^{\text{max}}_{n}\leq\underline{K}_{n}^{-1}\cdot\left(\frac{\underline{s}^{\text{DT}}_{n}}{\bar{r}^{\text{DT}}_{n}}+\frac{\underline{s}^{\text{UT}}_{n}}{\bar{r}^{\text{UT}}_{n}}\right)^{-1}\triangleq\bar{p}^{\text{max}}_{n} (33)

Thus, the operator can set the uniform prices as

pnm=p0+m⋅p¯nmax−p0M+1,∀m={1,…,M}formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑚𝑛subscript𝑝0⋅𝑚subscriptsuperscript¯𝑝max𝑛subscript𝑝0𝑀1for-all𝑚1…𝑀\displaystyle p^{m}_{n}=p_{0}+m\cdot\frac{\bar{p}^{\text{max}}_{n}-p_{0}}{M+1},\forall m=\{1,...,M\} (34)

Note that there is an intrinsic trade-off on the choice of M𝑀M. On the one hand, a large M𝑀M allows the pseudo-BDF and pseudo-MVF to more accurately reflect the true BDF and MVF at an increased complexity and signaling overhead. On the other hand, a smaller M𝑀M makes multi-biding easier but the discrepancy between the pseudo functions and the true functions will introduce a larger performance loss.

VI Simulations

In this section, we conduct simulations to evaluate the performance of the proposed methods.

VI-A Simulation Setup

The simulated wireless network adopts an OFDMA system with a total bandwidth of B=10𝐵10B=10 MHz. The period length is set as T=20​s𝑇20𝑠T=20s. The number of clients of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25. In every period, a new FL task may start following a scheduled plan, which is defined by a Poisson distribution with the mean interval parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}}. By tuning parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}}, we adjust the FL service demand, and a smaller parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}} will more likely lead to more concurrent FL services in a period as an FL service often lasts multiple periods. Each FL service has a pre-determined target training accuracy, and when the accuracy reaches the target, the FL service terminates and exits the wireless network. The clients’ wireless channel gain is modeled as independent free-space fading where the average path loss is from a Normal distribution with different mean and variance in different circumstances. The variance of the complex white Gaussian channel noise is set as 10−12superscript101210^{-12}. For each client, the local training time is uniformly randomly drawn from [0.01,0.05]0.010.05[0.01,0.05] s. We fix the global aggregation time to be 1×10−51superscript1051\times 10^{-5}. We consider typical neural network sizes in the range of [0.2,0.5]0.20.5[0.2,0.5] Mbits. The upload transmission power is uniformly randomly between 0.05 and 0.15 W, and the download transmission power is uniformly randomly between 0.1 and 0.3 W.

VI-B Convergence of DISBA in the Cooperative Case

We first illustrate the convergence behavior of DISBA in the cooperative FL service provider case in a representative period with 5 concurrent FL services. These services have 10, 12, 14, 16, 18 clients, respectively. In Figure 5, we show the computed FL frequency for each service provider before convergence. As Figure 5 shows, the bandwidth allocation quickly converges to the optimal allocation for a convergence tolerance gap ϵ=1​e−3italic-ϵ1𝑒3\epsilon=1e-3. Eventually, the resulting FL frequencies of these FL services in this period are reported in Table I. We further show in Table II the computation time of DISBA for different values of the tolerance gap and step size. The time values are measured on a desktop computer with Intel Core i5-9400 2.9GHz GPU and 16GB memory.

VI-C Fairness-adjusted Multi-bid Auction in the Selfish Case

We perform fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction in the same representative period as in the last subsection, with M=5𝑀5M=5 and α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5. The pseudo-mBDFs of the FL service providers and the aggregated pseudo-mBDF are illustrated in Figures 7 and 7, respectively. The pseudo-MCP is also shown in Figure 7. Table III reports the resulting bandwidth allocation and achieved FL frequency.

As we briefly mentioned in Section V, there is a trade-off when selecting the number of bids M𝑀M. On the one hand, a larger M𝑀M increases the computational complexity for searching for the pseudo-MCP and determining the eventual bandwidth allocation. On the other hand, a larger M𝑀M improves the precision of the pseudo-MCP, thereby improving the allocation performance. In Figure 8, we demonstrate the overall performance by varying M𝑀M. As can be seen, as M𝑀M increases, the overall performance will increase while each FL service provider needs to submit more bids to the server which will cause transmission delays and data backlogs.

The parameter α𝛼\alpha plays an important role in the selfish owner case, which makes a tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. With a larger α𝛼\alpha, the whole system sees fairness as more important, and conversely, the whole system is more concerned with the overall efficiency. The market clearing price is reflected in Figure 10 and the overall utility is shown in Figure 10. With the increase of α𝛼\alpha, the market clearing price and the total utility will decrease, which can be treated as a concession to achieve fairness between different FL services.

VI-D Performance Comparison

In the following experiments, we compare our proposed algorithms with three benchmark algorithms.

  • •

    Equal-Client (EC): Bandwidth is equally allocated to the clients. Therefore, each client gets a bandwidth of B/∑nKn𝐵subscript𝑛subscript𝐾𝑛B/\sum_{n}K_{n}.

  • •

    Equal-Service (ES): Bandwidth is equally allocated to the FL services. That is, each FL service gets a bandwidth of B/N𝐵𝑁B/N. However, each FL service provider still performs the optimal intra-service bandwidth allocation among its clients.

  • •

    Proportional (PP): Each FL service obtains a bandwidth that is proportional to the number of its client. That is, FL service n𝑛n obtains a bandwidth of Kn∑jKn​Bsubscript𝐾𝑛subscript𝑗subscript𝐾𝑛𝐵\frac{K_{n}}{\sum_{j}K_{n}}B. This bandwidth is further allocated among its clients following the optimal intra-service bandwidth allocation.

We start by comparing the proposed algorithms with benchmarks in the per-period setting. The overall performance is shown in Figure 11. In this setting, there are five FL services with a random number of clients drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 20 and variance 10 and random channel conditions drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and variance 15, and the result is averaged over 20 runs. As can be seen, our DISBA algorithm for the cooperative case (labeled as Coop) has the best performance, and the auction mechanism for the selfish case (labeled as Self) also outperforms the other benchmarks. Although ES and PP also perform the intra-service bandwidth allocation, the heterogeneity of the client number and channel conditions render them suboptimal.

Because FL is a long-term process, we further investigate the long-term performance of the proposed algorithms. In the long-term setting, 10 FL services join the wireless network at different times controlled by the parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}}-parameterized Poisson process and the FL service will be removed from the wireless network when its test accuracy has converged. Although the convergence of FL is complexly affected by many factors including the adopted FL algorithm, dataset and the selected clients, we assume that each of these 10 FL services require 2000 FL rounds, which is a typical value observed in the literature [2], to reach convergence in order to provide a meaningful comparison of the algorithms in a controlled environment. Whenever a FL service has been run for 2000 rounds, it exits the system.

Figure 12 illustrates the average duration (in terms of the number of periods) of all FL services by running different algorithms for parrive=5subscript𝑝arrive5p_{\text{arrive}}=5, where the client number of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25 and variance 15 and the channel condition of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and variance 15. The results are averaged over 20 runs. We can see that the proposed algorithms achieve the smallest average duration compared to the benchmarks, confirming their fast FL convergence even in the long-run.

Next, we study the impact of the client number heterogeneity (which reflects the FL service size heterogeneity) on the performance of different algorithms. To this end, the client number of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25 and we change the variance between 0 and 15 to adjust the heterogeneity degree. The result is shown in Figure 13: as the variance increases (i.e. a higher degree of heterogeneity), the mean of the average duration decreases, while the standard deviation of average duration increases. This is understandable because a higher degree of heterogeneity causes wireless bandwidth to be more unevenly distributed among the FL services, thereby degrading the overall FL performance. Notably, the performance gain of our proposed algorithms increases as the variance increases, which demonstrates the superior ability of our algorithms to handle the heterogeneous case.

Furthermore, we also investigate the impact of the channel condition heterogeneity on the FL performance. In these simulations, the average channel condition of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and we change the variance between 0 and 15 to adjust the heterogeneity degree. The channel conditions of clients of this FL are further drawn from a Normal distribution with a mean being the instantiated average channel condition. In Figure 14, we observe a similar phenomenon as in Figure 13, which further confirms the advantage of adopting our proposed algorithms.

Finally, we study the influence of the mean arrival interval parameter parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}} on the resulting average FL duration. in Figure 15, with the increasing of parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}}, the average duration of the FL services decreases. This is because when parrivesubscript𝑝arrivep_{\text{arrive}} is small, many FL services pile up and co-exist in the wireless network, thereby reducing the wireless bandwidth an individual FL service can receive.

VII Conclusion

This paper studied a bandwidth allocation problem for multiple FL services in a wireless network, which has not been well studied in the literature. The considered problem consists of two interconnected subproblems, intra-service resource allocation, and inter-service resource allocation. By solving these problems, we optimally allocate bandwidth resources to multiple FL services and their corresponding clients to speed up the training process and meanwhile guarantee fairness for both cooperative and selfish FL service providers cases. Our method has shown superior performance compared to the benchmarks. However, there are several future research works that can be done to extend the impact of this work. For example, this paper takes FL frequency as the key metric to be optimized, but the true performance of FL is affected by the dataset, federated optimization algorithm, and many others. In addition, when a client can simultaneously participate in multiple FL services, resource allocation has to consider both the wireless bandwidth and client computing resources.
